document.docAuthor: Huber, Bernhard A. & Meng, Guanliang & Valdez-Mondragón, Alejandro
document.docTitle: Notes on Chisosa (Araneae, Pholcidae), with the description of a new species from Mexico

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Notes on Chisosa (Araneae, Pholcidae), with the description of a new species from Mexico

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig, LIB, Bonn, Germany.
Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig, LIB, Bonn, Germany.

emphasis.docTitle:
Notes on
Chisosa
( Araneae , Pholcidae ), with the description of a new species from Mexico

subSection.paragraph: BERNHARD A. HUBER 1, 2, * , GUANLIANG MENG 1, 3 & ALEJANDRO VALDEZ-MONDRAGÓN 4

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Zoological Research Museum Alexander Koenig, LIB, Bonn, Germany .

subSection.paragraph:
2
�
b.huber@leibniz-lib.de ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-7566-5424

3
�
G. Meng@leibniz-lib.de ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0002-6488-1527

4 Colección de Aracnología (CARCIB), Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas del Noroeste CIBNOR, S.C., La Paz,
Baja California Sur
, México .
�
lat_mactans@yahoo.com.mx ; https://orcid.org/ 0000-0001-5385-3195

* Corresponding author:
� b.huber@leibniz-lib.de

The genus
Chisosa Huber, 2000
previously included only three species of small to tiny North American and Caribbean spiders that are rare in collections and poorly studied. Originally placed in the subfamily Ninetinae ,
Chisosa
is currently considered a representative of Arteminae, close to the North American genus
Physocyclus Simon, 1893
. This placement has been suggested by molecular data, and it affects the interpretation of morphological characters that were originally thought to support the monophyly of
Chisosa
: they are shared with
Physocyclus
and thus plesiomorphic for
Chisosa
. Here we describe a new species from Mexico ,
C. calapa
sp. nov.
, and restudy in detail the morphology (incl. ultrastructure) of the type species
C. diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
and of
C. caquetio Huber, 2019
, based on newly collected material. We document further similarities with
Physocyclus
but find only weak morphological support for the monophyly of
Chisosa
(body size reduction and short legs). In addition, we document surprisingly large genetic distances among
C. caquetio
specimens from Curaçao (>14% CO1 K2P distances), possibly indicating species limits. Finally, we propose that the Dominican amber genus
Serratochorus Wunderlich, 1988
, based on a single male specimen, is also phylogenetically close to
Chisosa
and should be included in future studies on these enigmatic spiders.

Key words : Arteminae , Caribbean , CO 1 barcoding , North America ,
Physocyclus
,
Serratochorus

When Gertsch & Mulaik (1940) described some tiny female spiders that had been collected in southern Texas two years earlier, they placed them in the Ninetinae genus
Pholcophora Banks, 1896
, as
Pholcophora diluta
. They did not explain their rationale for this generic assignment, but it was probably the small size of the spiders, their relatively short legs, and maybe also the “obsolete median groove” that guided their decision.

More than 40 years later, Gertsch (1982) finally described the male of this species. He noted that the male palp was “very complicated”. This was in strong contrast to the type species
P. americana Banks, 1896
and other North American spiders at that time included in
Pholcophora
, but Gertsch did not change the generic assignment. Later, in a revision of New World pholcids ( Huber 2000 ), it became clear that
Pholcophora
had turned into a waste basket of tiny New World pholcids and several species were transferred to newly created genera, like
Galapa Huber, 2000
;
Guaranita Huber, 2000
;
Tolteca Huber, 2000
; and
Chisosa Huber, 2000
. The latter originally included only two species, both transferred from
Pholcophora
: the type species
C. diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
and
C. baja ( Gertsch, 1982 )
, a species from Baja California known from a single male specimen.A third species was added only recently:
C. caquetio Huber, 2019
, at that time known from the Netherlands Antilles and the northern Venezuelan coast ( Huber & Carvalho 2019 ; Huber & Villarreal 2020 ).

The type species
C. diluta
was included in a first morphological cladistic analysis of the family ( Huber 2000 ), weakly supporting the position of the genus in Ninetinae . In 2018,
C. diluta
was included in a molecular phylogenetic analysis (
Eberle et al. 2018
), and the results indicated that the species did not belong to Ninetinae but to Arteminae, a subfamily otherwise represented in North America only by
Physocyclus Simon, 1893
.
Physocyclus
spiders are superficially very different from
Chisosa
, with usually much larger bodies, longer legs, and with deep thoracic grooves, but an upcoming analysis of UCE data (G. Meng, B.A. Huber, L. Podsiadlowski, unpubl. data) suggests that these two unequal neighbors are in fact not only phylogenetically close but sister taxa.

Compared to
Physocyclus
(currently 39 species),
Chisosa
continues to be poorly known and previously included only the three species above. The main purpose of this paper, apart from describing a fourth species based on morphological and genetic data, is a first comprehensive analysis of SEM data of
Chisosa
, made possible by recent collections of larger series of two of the three previously known species. In addition, we tentatively propose that another, even more enigmatic genus may also be close to
Chisosa
and needs further study: the monotypic genus
Serratochorus Wunderlich, 1988
, based on a single male specimen preserved in Dominican amber ( Wunderlich 1988 ).

This study is based on the examination of specimens deposited in the following collections:Colección de Aracnología, Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas del Noroeste CIBNOR, S.C., La Paz, Baja California Sur , Mexico (CARCIB); Senckenberg Museum Frankfurt, Germany (SMF); and Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum Alexander Koenig, Bonn, Germany (ZFMK). ZFMK material with Ar codes is kept in 80% ethanol at room temperature; material with other codes is in pure ethanol at -18°C.

Taxonomic descriptions follow the style of recent publications on
Chisosa
(e.g., Huber & Carvalho 2019 ; Huber & Villarreal 2020 ; based on Huber 2000 ). Measurements were done on a dissecting microscope with an ocular grid and are in mm unless otherwise noted; eye measurements are +/- 5 µm. Photos were partly made using a Zeiss Axio Zoom V.16 microscope and Axio Zoom Zen and Zen Pro digital software, partly with a Nikon Coolpix 995 digital camera (2048 x 1536 pixels) mounted on a Nikon SMZ 18 stereo microscope or a Leitz Dialux 20 compound microscope. CombineZP (https://combinezp.software.informer.com/) was used for stacking photos. Drawings are partly based on photos that were traced on a light table and later improved under a dissecting microscope, or they were directly drawn with a Leitz Dialux 20 compound microscope using a drawing tube. Cleared epigyna were stained with chlorazol black. For scanning electron microscope (SEM) photos, specimens were dried in hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) ( Brown 1993 ), sputter-coated with gold, and photographed with a Zeiss Sigma 300 VP scanning electron microscope. The number of decimals in coordinates gives a rough indication of the accuracy of the locality data: four decimals means that the collecting site (or cave entrance) is within about 10 m of the indicated spot; three decimals: within ~
100 m .
The distribution map was generated with ArcMap 10.0. Abbreviations used in the text: ALE = anterior lateral eye(s); ALS = anterior lateral spinneret(s); AME = anterior median eye(s); a.s.l. = above sea level; L/d = length/diameter; PME = posterior median eye(s); PMS = posterior median spinneret(s). Abbreviations used in figures only are explained in the figure legends.

Taxonomic sampling. We newly generated CO1 barcodes of ten specimens of representatives of
Chisosa
( Table 1 ). To this we added nine previously published CO1 barcodes from
Eberle et al. (2018)
and Nolasco & Valdez-Mondragón (2022) : three further
Chisosa
specimens; four species representing the putative sister genus
Physocyclus Simon, 1893
; one further representative of Arteminae,
Nita elsaff Huber & El Hennawy, 2007
; and, for rooting the tree, the Modisiminae
Arenita fazendinha Huber & Carvalho, 2019
.

DNA extraction, amplification and sequencing. Two to four legs of specimens stored in non-denatured pure ethanol (~99%) at -18°C were used for DNA extraction. Extracted genomic DNA is deposited at and available from the LIB Biobank, Museum Koenig, Bonn. DNA was extracted using the BioSprint® 96 DNA Blood Kit (Qiagen). The CO1 primers used were LCO1490-JJ and HCO2198-JJ (
Astrin et al. 2016
; primer versions JJ2 served as backup). The 20 µl reaction volume consisted of 4.4 µl H 2 O, 2 µl DNA template, 2 µl Q-Solution, 10 µl Qiagen Multiplex-Mix, 0.8 µl forward primer and 0.8 µl reverse primer. The PCR program ran two cycle sets, as a combination of a ‘touchdown’ and a ‘step-up’ routine: (1) 15 min hot start Taq activation at 95°C; (2) first cycle set (15 repeats): 35 s denaturation at 94°C, 90 s annealing at 55°C (−1°C per cycle) and 90 s extension at 72°C; (3) second cycle set (25 repeats): 35 s denaturation at 94°C, 90 s annealing at 40°C, and 90 s extension at 72°C; (4) final elongation 10 min at 72°C. PCR products were sent for bidirectional Sanger sequencing to BGI ( Hong Kong , China ).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 1. Geographic origins and GenBank accession numbers of
Chisosa
specimens, sorted as in Fig. 1. Newly generated sequences are in bold. Other sequences are from
Eberle et al. (2018)
(S430) and Nolasco & Valdez-Mondragón
(2022) (ARA codes). For the complete set of taxa used for the NJ tree, see Supplementary File, Table S1.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Chisosa Huber, 2000: 124
; type species:
Pholcophora diluta Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940
.

subSection.paragraph:
Molecular (UCE) data strongly support the monophyly of
Chisosa
, placing the newly described
C. calapa
as sister to the also highly supported clade
C. diluta
+
C. caquetio
(G. Meng, B.A. Huber, L. Podsiadlowski, unpubl. data). The putative sister of
Chisosa
is
Physocyclus
; together they form the North and Central American and Caribbean clade within a group called “other Arteminae” in
Huber et al. (2018)
(i.e., of Arteminae except
Artema
). The relationships of these two North American genera with the Chilean genus
Aucana Huber, 2000
and other undescribed South American putative ‘Arteminae’ (B.A. Huber, unpubl. data) remain to be established.

Our topology ( Fig. 1 ) suggests a different relationship among
Chisosa species
, but, being a CO1 NJ tree, it is not supposed to reflect phylogenetic relationships. Rather than that, it shows some surprisingly large genetic distances among putative conspecifics, which will be detailed in the sections on
C. diluta
and
C. caquetio
below.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Neighbor-joining tree of CO1 sequences analyzed using the Kimura 2-parameter model. Branch supports are standard bootstrap values calculated from 500 replications (for the same tree using 5000 replications, see Fig. S1). Live spider:
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
; male from U.S.A., Texas, Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon.

subSection.paragraph:
Chisosa
spiders occur in open, semi-arid environments ( Fig. 2 ), where they live under stones and in the sparse leaf litter, but also in caves, where they seem to be restricted to the twilight area. Upon turning the stone or moving the leaves, the spiders start to run quickly for a short time and then stop abruptly or drop to the ground. No webs were seen in the field.
The genus ranges from Southern Texas and Baja California to the southeastern Caribbean, including the northern South American coast ( Fig. 3 ).

The genus now includes four nominal species: the three treated below, plus
C. baja ( Gertsch, 1982 )
which is known from a single male specimen (redescribed in Huber 2000 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Known geographic distribution of
Chisosa Huber, 2000
, and geographic origin of
Serratochorus pygmaeus Wunderlich, 1988
.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Chisosa diluta
–
Huber 2000: 125
, figs 151, 478–489.
Eberle et al. 2018
(molecular data).
Huber et al. 2018
: fig. 2.

subSection.paragraph:
Previously, this species was known from only a few specimens collected in Big Bend National Park in 1938 and 1967. The new records below show that the species is still present in the area and probably abundant. The molecular phylogenetic analysis of
Eberle et al. (2018)
used a newly collected specimen from the type locality (Hot Springs). The karyotype analysis of
Ávila Herrera et al. (2021)
is based on specimens from Tuff Canyon; the coordinates given there (their table S6) are wrong (first decimal missing: 29.50, -103.88; correct coordinates 29.150 , -103.488 ). Our upcoming analysis of UCE data (Meng et al. , unpubl. data) uses specimens from Tuff Canyon.

Easily distinguished from known congeners by male cheliceral armature: two large distal lateral processes directed towards the front ( Fig. 6A, B ) (congeners with several but much smaller processes); and by female epigynum: pair of large dark pockets at posterior margin on main (anterior) epigynal plate ( Figs 5D , 10A–C ) (congeners without pockets – female of
C. baja
unknown).

USA :
Texas
: Brewster County, Big Bend National Park • 2 ♀ , in pure ethanol; Hot Springs; 29.177 °N , 103.001 °W ; 565 m a.s.l.; under stones at riverbank; 28 Jun. 2016 ; B.A. Huber leg.; ZFMK USA 20 • 1 ♀ , 1 juv. , in pure ethanol; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK USA 27 • 2 ♂ , 5 ♀ , one male abdomen used for SEM; Tuff Canyon; 29.150 °N , 103.488 °W ; 710 m a.s.l.; under rocks; 29 Jun. 2016 ; B.A. Huber leg.; ZFMK Ar 24229 • 1 ♂ , 1 ♀ ; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK Ar 24230 • 3 ♀ , in pure ethanol, one female used for SEM; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK USA 18 • 3 ♀ , in pure ethanol, two prosomata used for molecular work; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK USA 26 • 2 ♂ , in pure ethanol, one prosoma used for SEM, both abdomens used for karyological work; same collection data as for preceding; vouchers of
Ávila Herrera et al. (2021)
; ZFMK Kra59, Kra60 • 1 ♀ , in pure ethanol; Santa Elena ; 29.156 °N , 103.597 °W ; 665 m a.s.l.; under rocks near road; 29 Jun. 2016 ; B.A. Huber leg.; ZFMK USA 19 • 1 ♂ , in pure ethanol; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK Kra49.

, male from U.S.A., Texas, Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon. C, D.

subSection.paragraph: Redescription (amendments; see Huber 2000 )

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
; male and female from Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon; ZFMK USA6 (male) and ZFMK USA18 (female). A. Female prosoma, frontal dorsal view. B. Female ocular area, frontal dorsal view. C. Male gonopore. D. Epigynum; arrows point at pockets. E. Male anterior lateral spinneret. F. Female anterior lateral spinneret (ALS) and posterior median spinneret (PMS). Scale lines: 100 µm (A, B, D); 10 µm (C, E, F).

FIGURE 6.
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
; male from Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon; ZFMK Kra60. A, B. Male chelicerae, frontal and oblique lateral views. C. Stridulatory pick on male palpal femur. D. Male palpal tarsal organ. E. Left tarsus and procursus, retrolateral view. F. Right bulbal process with sperm duct opening (arrow). Abbreviations: b, genital bulb; pr, procursus; ta, tarsus. Scale lines: 100 µm (A, B, E), 10 µm (C, D, F).

subSection.paragraph: Apparently without stridulatory files on chelicerae (not seen clearly). With short chemoreceptive hairs like in male but without sexually dimorphic short ‘vertical’ hairs. Epigynum with pair of large pockets ( Figs 5D , 10A–C ), distance between deepest parts ~210 µm; internal genitalia ( Fig. 10D–I ) with pair of round to oval pore plates bordered by strong sclerite; anteriorly with strong transversal sclerite without anterior median projection.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. CO1 Kimura 2-parameter (K2P) genetic distances among sequenced
Chisosa
specimens, calculated from the untrimmed alignment using MEGA 11. Pairwise deletion strategy was used to deal with gaps/missing data in the alignment. Taxa are sorted as in Fig. 1. Bold: intraspecific distances. For the complete matrix including outgroups, see Supplementary File, Table S2.

subSection.paragraph: Tibia 1 in six males : 1.30–1.41 (mean 1.34); in 16 females : 1.10–1.32 (mean 1.22). The distance between the pore plates is slightly variable but this rests on a very limited number of cleared female genitalia (three). Two cleared females from Tuff Canyon show that there is considerable variation even within this population (compare Fig. 10G and 10I ). Genetic distances among sequenced specimens ( Table 2 ) mirrored geographic distances: Tuff Canyon versus Santa Elena ( 12 km ): 0.5%; the two previous versus Hot Springs ( 47–60 km ): 6.5–6.9%.

The newly collected specimens were found by turning stones in open terrain ( Fig. 2A, B ). This type of microhabitat is abundant in the area, suggesting that the species is probably also abundant. Upon disturbance, the spiders started to run quickly and erratically. After a few seconds, they either stopped abruptly, making them difficult to see on the same-colored stones, or they dropped to the ground. A newly collected egg sac contained ten eggs, with an egg diameter of 0.45.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
; male and female from Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon; ZFMK Kra60 (male) and ZFMK USA18 (female). A. Stridulatory file on left male chelicera. B. Female left metatarsus 4, retrolateral view; arrow: putative chemoreceptor; asterisk: ‘cuticular plate’ of unknown function. C, D. Sexually dimorphic ‘vertical’ hairs (arrows) on male tibia 1 (prolateral and retrolateral views). E, F. Tarsal claws on female right tarsus 1 (prolateral view) and female left tarsus 4 (retrolateral view); arrows: putative chemoreceptors. Scale lines: 10 µm.

subSection.paragraph: Known from three localities in Big Bend National Park, Texas , USA ( Fig. 3 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 8.
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
; male and female from Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon; ZFMK Kra60 (male) and ZFMK USA18 (female). A. Prolateral trichobothrium on right female tibia 2. B. Retrolateral trichobothrium on left male tibia 2. C. Cuticular plate (arrow) on male left metatarsus 3. D, E. Slender metatarsal hairs (arrows) on female left metatarsus 4 and on female right metatarsus 3. F. Distinctively widened tip of slender metatarsal hair on female left metatarsus 3. Scale lines: 10 µm (A–E); 1 µm (F).

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Chisosa caquetio Huber
, in
Huber & Carvalho 2019: 31
, figs 105–113 ( ♂ ♀ ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
“Gen.n. Geneve59” –
Eberle et al. 2018
(molecular data).
Huber et al. 2018
: fig. 2.

subSection.paragraph:
This species was first described from Curaçao and Aruba ( Huber & Carvalho 2019 ) and later recorded also from coastal Venezuela ( Falcón , La Guaira) ( Huber & Villarreal 2020 ). The molecular phylogenetic analysis of
Eberle et al. (2018)
used a specimen from the type locality ( Curaçao : Jan Kok Lodges). Our upcoming analysis of UCE data (Meng et al. , unpubl. data) uses a specimen from Venezuela (Cueva del Guano).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9.
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
; male and female from Big Bend N.P., Tuff Canyon; ZFMK Kra60 (male) and ZFMK USA18 (female). A. Tarsal organ on male left tarsus 1. B. Tarsal organ on male left tarsus 2. C. Tip of male left tarsus 3, showing position of tarsal organ (arrow). D. Tarsal organ on male left tarsus 4. E. Tarsal organ on female left tarsus 1. F. Tarsal organ on female left tarsus 3. Scale lines: 2 µm (A, E–F); 10 µm (B–D).

subSection.paragraph:
Distinguished from known congeners by armature of male chelicerae: four pairs of cone-shaped sclerotized processes laterally; without median pair as in the similar
C. calapa
(see figs 107–108 in Huber & Carvalho 2019 ); by shape of procursus; small dorsal process; dorsal process much larger in
C. baja
and
C. calapa
(see fig. 106 in Huber & Carvalho 2019 ); and by epigynum and internal female genitalia ( Fig. 15 ): without external pockets (as opposed to
C. diluta
), with round to oval pore plates (much smaller than in congeners – female of
C. baja
unknown); from
C. diluta
also by smaller AME; from
C. calapa
also by smaller body size, shorter legs, absence of thoracic groove, and absence of sclerotized median structure in female internal genitalia.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10.
Chisosa diluta ( Gertsch & Mulaik, 1940 )
, from Big Bend N.P.; female from Hot Springs (A, D, E), ZFMK USA20; and two females from Tuff Canyon (B, C, F–I); ZFMK USA26. A–C. Abdomens, ventral views. D, F, H. Cleared genitalia, ventral views. E, G, I. Cleared genitalia, dorsal views. Note slight genitalic variation, especially in distance between pore plates. Abbreviation: pp, pore plate. Scale lines: 0.2 mm.

FIGURE 11.
Chisosa caquetio Huber, 2019
; male from Landhuis San Pedro (ZFMK Ar 24207), female from Kueba di Brua (ZFMK Cur43). A. Female prosoma, frontal dorsal view. B. Male gonopore. C. Male anterior lateral spinneret (ALS). D. Female ALS and posterior median spinnerets (PMS). E. Cone-shaped processes on left male chelicera, frontal view. F. Stridulatory file on left male chelicera. Scale lines: 100 µm (A); 10 µm (B, D–F); 2 µm (C).

subSection.paragraph: CURAÇAO • 3 ♂ , 4 ♀ , one male used for SEM; near Landhuis San Pedro; 12.2568 °N , 69.0455 °W ; 30 m a.s.l.; 9 Jun. 2022 ; B.A. Huber leg.; ZFMK Ar 24207 • 4 ♀ , in pure ethanol; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK Cur41 • 1 ♂ , 2 ♀ ; N of Tera Kora, Kueba di Brua; 12.2356 °N , 69.0292 °W ; 20 m a.s.l.; in cave; 9 Jun. 2022 ; B.A. Huber leg.; ZFMK Ar 24208 • 9 ♀ , in pure ethanol, two females used for SEM; same collection data as for preceding; ZFMK Cur43.
SAINT VINCENT AND THE GRENADINES • 1 ♂ ; St. Vincent, Young Island; 13.1306 °N , 61.2027 °W ; 25 m a.s.l.; 30 Oct. 2004 ; S. Crews leg.; ZFMK Ar 5173.

subSection.paragraph: Redescription (amendments; see Huber & Carvalho 2019 )

Sexually monomorphic short vertical hair (putative chemoreceptor). C. Cuticular plate (arrow) on female left metatarsus 3. D. Trichobothrium on female metatarsus 4. E. Slender metatarsal hairs (arrows) on female left metatarsus 4, retrolateral view. H. Distinctively widened tip of slender metatarsal hair on female left metatarsus 4. Scale lines: 10 µm (A, D–G); 1 µm (B); 2 µm (C, H).

FIGURE 14.
Chisosa caquetio Huber, 2019
; male from Landhuis San Pedro (ZFMK Ar 24207), female from Kueba di Brua (ZFMK Cur43). A, B. Tips of female right tarsi 1 and 2, prolateral views. C. Tip of male right tarsus 4, prolateral view. D. Tarsal organ and slit sensillum on female right tarsus 1. E. Tarsal organ and slit sensillum on male right tarsus 2. F. Tarsal organ and slit sensillum on female right tarsus 3. Scale lines: 10 µm (A–C, F); 2 µm (D, E).

FIGURE 15.
Chisosa caquetio Huber, 2019
; two females from Kueba di Brua; ZFMK Cur43. A, B. Abdomens, ventral views. C, E. Cleared genitalia, ventral views. D, F. Cleared genitalia, dorsal views. Abbreviations: aep, anterior (main) epigynal plate; pep, posterior epigynal plate; pp, pore plate. Scale lines: 0.2 mm (A, B), 0.1 mm (C–F).

subSection.paragraph: Tibia 1 in 15 males : 0.48–0.72 (mean 0.61); in 44 females : 0.46–0.75 (mean 0.60). As noted earlier ( Huber & Carvalho 2019 ), specimens from caves tend to have longer legs. This is also true for the newly collected specimens, where the cave (Kueba di Brua) is only 3 km from the epigean locality (Landhuis San Pedro ): tibia 1 in nine females from Kueba di Brua: 0.60–0.75 (mean 0.70), in eight females from Landhuis San Pedro : 0.57–0.66 (mean 0.61). In addition, island specimens tend to have longer legs than mainland specimens, irrespective of habitat: tibia 1 in nine island males: 0.57–0.72 (mean 0.68); in six mainland males: 0.48–0.54 (mean 0.51); tibia 1 in 34 island females: 0.50–0.75 (mean 0.63); in ten mainland females: 0.46–0.53 (mean 0.49).
As noted earlier, males from Aruba differ slightly with respect to palp and chelicerae morphology ( Huber & Carvalho 2019 ). No such variation was found among the other specimens.

Genetic (CO1) distances between specimens from different localities ranged from 1.6% ( Curaçao : Landhuis San Pedro versus Kueba di Brua), to 9.0% ( Curaçao : Jan Kock Lodges versus Venezuela : Catia La Mar), and 14.4– 14.9% between these two groups ( Table 2 ). The latter distances are in Pholcidae usually considered clear indicators of species limits; see Discussion below.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 16.
Chisosa calapa
sp. nov.
; males and females from W of Calapa bridge, Puebla, Mexico; ZFMK Ar 24231. A–D. Live specimens in dorsal and lateral views. E, F. Male and female in ethanol, dorsal views. Scale lines: 1.0 mm.

subSection.paragraph:
The newly collected specimens from Curaçao were partly found in dry leaf litter among large rocks ( Fig. 2C ), partly under stones in the twilight zone of a cave ( Fig. 2D ). In both places, they shared the microhabitat, and sometimes the individual stones, with
Modisimus culicinus (Simon, 1893)
and with juveniles of
Physocyclus globosus (Taczanowski, 1874)
, both of which were much more abundant than
C. caquetio
. Two newly collected egg sacs contained five and nine eggs , respectively, with an egg diameter of 0.40.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 17.
Chisosa calapa
sp. nov.
; left male palp of holotype, CARCIB-Ara-046; prolateral, dorsal, and retrolateral views; arrows point at femur-patella joints. Scale line: 0.5 mm.

figureCitation.captionText-0: FIGURE 16. Chisosa calapa sp. nov.; males and females from W of Calapa bridge, Puebla, Mexico; ZFMK Ar 24231. A–D. Live specimens in dorsal and lateral views. E, F. Male and female in ethanol, dorsal views. Scale lines: 1.0 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURE 17. Chisosa calapa sp. nov.; left male palp of holotype, CARCIB-Ara-046; prolateral, dorsal, and retrolateral views; arrows point at femur-patella joints. Scale line: 0.5 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-2: FIGURE 18. Chisosa calapa sp. nov.; male from W of Calapa bridge, Puebla, Mexico; ZFMK Ar 24231. A–C. Left procursus, prolateral, dorsal, and retrolateral views. D–F. Left genital bulb, prolateral, dorsal, and retrolateral views; arrow points at sperm duct opening. G, H. Chelicerae, frontal and lateral views. Scale lines: 0.2 mm.
figureCitation.captionText-3: FIGURE 19. Chisosa calapa sp. nov.; from NW of Calapa bridge, Puebla, Mexico; CARCIB-Ara-046, CARCIB-Ara-0325 (A–C) and from W of Calapa bridge; ZFMK Ar 24231 (D–G). A. Male chelicerae of holotype, frontal view. B, C. Epigynum, specimen 1, ventral and lateral views. D. Epigynum, specimen 2, ventral view. E, F. Cleared genitalia, ventral and dorsal views; arrow points at “large trapezoidal internal structure” that may be homologous to a similar structure on the internal arc in Physocyclus. G. Detail from previous figure, showing membranous structures medially posteriorly.Abbreviation: pp, pore plate. Scale lines: 0.2 mm (A–F), 0.1 mm (G).

subSection.paragraph:
Easily distinguished from known congeners by shape of procursus ( Fig. 18A–C ): proximal part strongly widened in lateral view, distal part connecting to proximal part by constriction and consisting of distinctive black sclerotized element and transparent membranous elements (congeners without constriction between proximal and distal parts); by shape of genital bulb ( Fig. 18D–F ): large sclerotized process with numerous denticles on prolateral side (congeners without such sclerite); by armature of male chelicerae ( Figs 18G, H , 19A ): pair of cone-shaped sclerotized processes near laminae and four pairs of similar but shorter processes more proximally and laterally (
C. diluta
with only one pair of much larger processes, other congeners without pair of processes near laminae); and by shape of main epigynal plate ( Fig. 19B–D ): anteriorly medially whitish, posteriorly medially with low rounded process, without pockets (congeners without anterior median whitish area, without posterior process;
C. diluta
with pair of pockets – female of
C. baja
unknown).
The species name is taken from the type locality; noun in apposition.

MEXICO :
Puebla
• ♂ ; ~ 35 km SE of Tehuacán, Tehuacán-Cuicatlán Biosphere Reserve, NW of Calapa bridge, 18.1656° N , 97.2628° W ; 1070 m a.s.l.; 23 Oct. 2019 ; A. Valdez-Mondragón, A. Cabrera, and B.A. Huber leg.; CARCIB-Ara-046.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 18.
Chisosa calapa
sp. nov.
; male from W of Calapa bridge, Puebla, Mexico; ZFMK Ar 24231. A–C. Left procursus, prolateral, dorsal, and retrolateral views. D–F. Left genital bulb, prolateral, dorsal, and retrolateral views; arrow points at sperm duct opening. G, H. Chelicerae, frontal and lateral views. Scale lines: 0.2 mm.

subSection.paragraph:
MEXICO :
Puebla
• 1 ♀ , 3 juvs; same collection data as for holotype ; CARCIB-Ara-0325, CARCIB-Ara-0326 • 1 ♂ , 1 ♀ , and 1 ♀ abdomen transferred from ZFMK Mex351; same locality as holotype but W of Calapa bridge; 18.1619° N , 97.2647° W ; 1010 m a.s.l.; 23 Oct. 2019 ; B.A. Huber and A. Valdez-Mondragón leg.; ZFMK Ar 24231.

MEXICO :
Puebla
• 3 ♀ , in pure ethanol, one prosoma used for molecular work; same locality as holotype but W of Calapa bridge; 18.1619° N , 97.2647° W ; 1010 m a.s.l.; 23 Oct. 2019 ; B.A. Huber and A. Valdez-Mondragón leg.; ZFMK Mex351.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 19.
Chisosa calapa
sp. nov.
; from NW of Calapa bridge, Puebla, Mexico; CARCIB-Ara-046, CARCIB-Ara-0325 (A–C) and from W of Calapa bridge; ZFMK Ar 24231 (D–G). A. Male chelicerae of holotype, frontal view. B, C. Epigynum, specimen 1, ventral and lateral views. D. Epigynum, specimen 2, ventral view. E, F. Cleared genitalia, ventral and dorsal views; arrow points at “large trapezoidal internal structure” that may be homologous to a similar structure on the internal arc in
Physocyclus
. G. Detail from previous figure, showing membranous structures medially posteriorly. Abbreviation: pp, pore plate. Scale lines: 0.2 mm (A–F), 0.1 mm (G).

subSection.paragraph: Male ( paratype )
MEASUREMENTS. Total length 1.85, carapace width 0.88. Distance PME–PME 75 µm; diameter PME 70 x 80
µm; distance PME–ALE 40 µm; diameter AME 50 µm; distance AME–AME 15 µm. Leg 1: 11.80 (3.05 + 0.40 + 3.20 + 4.15 + 1.00), tibia 2: 2.60, tibia 3: 1.90, tibia 4: 2.50; tibia 1 L/d: 38.
COLOR (in ethanol). Carapace pale ochre-yellow, with dark median Y-mark; sternum whitish; legs pale ochre-yellow, without dark rings; abdomen monochromous pale greenish-gray.

BODY. Habitus as in Fig. 16A, C, E . Ocular area slightly raised. Thoracic groove shallow but distinct. Clypeus unmodified but rim slightly more sclerotized than in female. Sternum wider than long (0.64/0.50), unmodified. Abdomen globular.

CHELICERAE. As in Figs 18G, H , 19A ; with pair of sclerotized cone-shaped processes near laminae and four pairs of similar but shorter processes more proximally and laterally; with distinct stridulatory files (clearly visible in dissecting microscope).

LEGS. Without spines, with curved hairs on tibiae and metatarsi 1 and 2, with higher density of short ‘vertical’ hairs than in female; proximally ventrally on metatarsi 3 and 4 with slender hairs similar to congeners above; metatarsus 3 with one to two such hairs, metatarsus 4 with approximately four to six; retrolateral trichobothrium of tibia 1 at 39%; prolateral trichobothrium present on all tibiae; tarsal pseudosegments indistinct except a few (~5) distally.

The specimens were found by turning rocks in a semi-arid, open environment ( Fig. 2E, F ). They occupied the same microhabitat as
Physocyclus modestus Gertsch, 1971
, and were difficult to distinguish in the field from juveniles of that species. Upon turning the rock, the spiders started to run rapidly and dropped to the ground where they quickly disappeared.
Known from type locality only ( Fig. 3 ).

When
Chisosa
was established for two species previously placed in the Ninetinae genus
Pholcophora Banks
( Huber 2000 ), its placement in Ninetinae was tentative. A first morphological cladistic analysis weakly supported this placement, based on several similarities that must now be considered either convergencies or plesiomorphies: small size; short legs; tibia 1 about as long as (or shorter than) tibia 4; retrolateral trichobothria on leg tibiae in very distal position; few tarsal pseudosegments; carapace without thoracic grove. However, the fact that some of these characters might not be independent (e.g., all those listed above regarding legs) was explicitly pointed out ( Huber 2000: 18 ), and the cladistic analysis revealed character conflict created by the limited data available at that time on epiandrous spigots and tarsal organs. The monophyly of Ninetinae as circumscribed at that time was thus explicitly questioned ( Huber 2000: 41 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 20.
Serratochorus pygmaeus Wunderlich, 1988
; male holotype, SMF 38116. X-ray computed tomography images taken at the Centre for X-Ray Tomography at Ghent University (www.ugct.ugent.be/) using a nano-focus transmission type X-ray tube set at 50–80 keV and the program VGSTUDIO MAX 1.2 (www.volumegraphics.com) for 3D-visualisation of the projections. The images were kindly provided by Nadine Fischer in 2007. Scale line: 0.5 mm.

subSection.paragraph:
In the meantime, molecular data have strongly suggested that
Chisosa
had been misplaced in Ninetinae and in fact belongs to Arteminae, or rather “other Arteminae”, i.e. Arteminae except
Artema
(
Eberle et al. 2018
;
Huber et al. 2018
). This subfamily, or clade, is otherwise represented in North America only by the species-rich genus
Physocyclus Simon, 1893
. A consequence of this transfer, which is also strongly supported in our upcoming analyses of UCE data (G. Meng et al. , unpubl. data) is the monophyly of Ninetinae , i.e. a clade composed of all the genera placed in Ninetinae in Huber (2000) except for
Chisosa
and
Aucana
. A second consequence is that the morphological support for the monophyly of
Chisosa
is essentially lost. The two characters that in Huber (2000: 125) were considered to support the monophyly of
Chisosa
were unique among Ninetinae but are shared with
Physocyclus
: a large and complex procursus, and a large and strongly widened male palpal femur. Other characters that are probably derived in Pholcidae and that we describe herein for
Chisosa
are also shared with
Physocyclus
(and beyond): absence of epiandrous spigots; exposed (rather than capsulate) tarsal organs; presence of thin metatarsal hairs. This leaves only three characters as potential morphological synapomorphies of
Chisosa
: small body size, short legs, and the presence of sexually dimorphic short vertical hairs on the anterior tibiae of males. All these characters are highly homoplastic in Pholcidae and thus of limited phylogenetic value.

A similar situation occurs with respect to the putative sister-group relationship between
Chisosa
and
Physocyclus
. The two genera share gene sequences and the geographic region, but morphologically we do not see any potential synapomorphy. All the shared characters are either plesiomorphic within Pholcidae (e.g., full set of ALS spigots; presence of prolateral trichobothrium on tibia 1) or plesiomorphic within Arteminae (e.g., male chelicerae with sclerotized cone-shaped processes; widened male palpal femur).

Within
Chisosa
,
C. calapa
and
C. caquetio
(and
C. baja
, known from a single male specimen) share two morphological similarities that are absent in
C. diluta
, but these characters are also shared with
Physocyclus
(and beyond) and thus probably plesiomorphic: cheliceral armature (sclerotized cone-shaped processes); and absence of epigynal pockets. Epigynal pockets are present in a few species of
Physocyclus
, but their absence is considered to be plesiomorphic within the genus ( Valdez-Mondragón 2013 ). On the other hand, a sister group relationship between
C. diluta
and
C. caquetio
(as suggested by UCE data) is supported by several potential synapomorphies: (1) loss of female cheliceral stridulation; (2) loss of curved hairs on legs; (3) loss of thoracic groove; (4) small size. Interestingly, this scenario implies that
Chisosa
spiders, and in particular
C. diluta
and
C. caquetio
, may be miniaturized, derived from larger,
Physocyclus
-like ancestors.

Finally, the presence of curved hairs in
C. calapa
males suggests that this is not a synapomorphy of
Physocyclus
as suggested in the cladistic analysis of Valdez-Mondragón (2013 ; character 15). The “large trapezoidal internal structure” described above for
C. calapa
may also be homologous to the “sclerotized projection” on the internal arc in
Physocyclus
( Valdez-Mondragón 2013 ; character 12). It seems that
Chisosa calapa
has retained several plesiomorphic characters, which explains its superficial similarity with
Physocyclus
. In addition to curved hairs (and possibly the female internal arc structure), it retained a thoracic groove; relatively large body size and long legs compared to its congeners; and cheliceral stridulation in females.

paragraph.emphasis: Is Chisosa caquetio one or more species?

subSection.paragraph:
The morphological variation found among
C. caquetio
specimens is difficult to interpret. The genetic (CO1) distance between a short-legged epigean specimen from Curaçao (UH556) and a long-legged hypogean specimen from a neighboring locality (UH557) was only 1.6%, strongly suggesting conspecificity. Surprisingly, the distances between these two specimens from a third sequenced specimen from the type locality on Curaçao (BH162) were 14.4 and 14.9%, respectively. Such genetic distances are in Pholcidae usually correlated with clear morphological differences that are generally interpreted to indicate species boundaries (e.g.,
Astrin et al. 2006
; Valdez-Mondragón 2020 ; Nolasco and Valdez-Mondragón 2022 ;
Huber et al. 2023a
). In the present case, the morphological differences were minimal and limited to the female internal genitalia, and the type locality is less than 5 km from the two newly sampled localities.

The genetic distance between the topotypical specimen and two mainland specimens from Venezuela ( 285 km ) was 9.0%. This falls within a range where intra- and interspecific genetic (CO1) variation was found to overlap (
Astrin et al. 2006
: 8.7–10.9%) and that often characterizes ‘problematic’ species limits, where neither molecular nor morphological data suggest an easy answer concerning species limits (e.g.,
Huber et al. 2023b
). In sum, the high genetic distances, in particular among specimens from Curaçao , require confirmation and further study, and we suggest that the species should not be formally split until a larger sample of specimens from different localities has been sequenced and compared morphologically.

Serratochorus
is a monotypic genus, based on a single male specimen preserved in Dominican amber, described as
S. pygmaeus Wunderlich, 1988
. We have restudied this specimen in 2007, using both light microscopy and Xray computed tomography ( Fig. 20 ), but we were not able to add anything substantial to the original description by Wunderlich (1988) ; the results were thus not published. The reason we bring this up here is that we want to propose the idea of a potential close phylogenetic relationship or even synonymy of
Serratochorus
and
Chisosa
.
Serratochorus pygmaeus
appears in all respects similar to
Chisosa caquetio Huber, 2019
: (1) its total body length is 1.05 mm (
C. caquetio
: 0.8–0.9); (2) tibia 1 length: 0.64 (
C. caquetio
: 0.48–0.72); (3) the palps appear very similar (especially the large femur), even though we were not able to resolve the relevant details of the procursus and bulb; (4) the chelicerae are provided with short processes arranged in a pair of lateral rows on low crests. Adding to this, we note that Hispaniola, the geographic origin of
S. pygmaeus
, and the known geographic range of
C. caquetio
are much closer to each other than both are to other known species of
Chisosa
( Fig. 3 ). We refrain from formally synonymizing the two genera because this would result in a poorly known type species, unnecessarily complicating future work on extant species. We thus suggest that an effort should be made to discover further Dominican amber specimens (in particular a female; or even extant relatives on Hispaniola) before deciding on this formal issue.

We thank Sarah Crews for donating material from St. Vincent ; Julia Altman for sending in loan the type specimen of
Serratochorus pygmaeus
; Nadine Fischer for providing the X-ray computed tomography images; Samuel N. Garduño and Jana Thormann for help with molecular lab work; Alejandro Cabrera for help in the field ( Mexico ); Carlos Palacios-Cardiel for support in the storage of material at the Collection of Arachnology (CARCIB), CIBNOR; and Samuel N. Garduño for help with photographing
Chisosa calapa
specimens. We thank Charles Griswold, Maria Paula Pereira, and Ivan Magalhaes for helpful comments on the manuscript. BAH thanks David Larson, Jeffrey Bennet, and Raymond Skiles for support at Big Bend National Park, Texas. Unites States specimens were collected under permit BIBE-2016-SCI-0008. We thank Martin Brink (ABS National Focal Point, The Netherlands ) for information on collecting in Curaçao . AVM thanks the Program Cátedras CONACyT, Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnología (CONACyT), Mexico , for support of the project No. 59: “Laboratorio Regional de Biodiversidad y Cultivo de Tejidos Vegetales (LBCTV) del Instituto de Biología, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (IBUNAM), sede Tlaxcala ”; and SEP-CONACyT for financial support of the project Basic Science (Ciencia Básica) 2016, No. 282834, supporting field work in Mexico . The specimens from Mexico were collected under Scientific Collector Permit FAUT-0309 from the Secretaría de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales (SEMARNAT). Major financial support was provided by the German Research Foundation (DFG), project HU980/12-1.
